author: jgm
content: I'm not sure if the additional work is worth the effort.  A missed execution block feels more like a "no information => no change" situation rather than an "empty block => reduce base fee" situation.  The end result is likely to be more congestion in the following execution block, so reducing base fee in advance seems counter-intuitive.

author: potuz

author: potuz

author: bridge-bot
content:
<dankrad> I think this is a repeat discussion, but the "no information, no change" analogy is not good.
Let's say that the base fee is currently "correct", i.e. leads to exactly half full blocks.
Then the skipped block will lead to a decrease in basefee, and the next block will be 100% full so increase back to the previous level -> no change (after two blocks). This is good behaviour.
If instead it's "no change", then the next block will be 100% full and lead to an increase in base fee.  Doesn't make sense since the execution chain average load is still exactly the desired load (and EIP1559 is about saying that it's mostly average load that matters) (re @merge_chat_bot: <jgm> I'm not sure if the additional work is worth the effort.  A missed execution block feels more like a "no information => no change" situation rather than an "empty block => reduce base fee" situation.  The end result is likely to be more congestion in the following execution block, so reducing base fee in advance seems counter-intuitive.)

author: jgm
content: Not sure that it's unnecessary.  Say, for example, that every other block was missed on the consensus side.  That would result in a rough halving of the execution chain capacity and so I would expect to see a higher base fee as a result (assuming the same amount of gas consumed per second).

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> half of the blocks missing is a really extreme case

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> my point is, we have a mechamism that can keep capacity constant even if 10-20% of slots are missing and it seems sensible to design it like that. I don't think there's a downside

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> But I agree that it would need a special case when more than ~1/3  blocks are missing

author: jgm
content: <@!555483069038198827> yeah it was more illustrative.  Even if we're "only" missing 10% of blocks it does result in an overall reduction in capacity so I would expect base fee to rise under constant gas usage per second conditions.

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> it is a possible design decision but I think it's suboptimal. Yes the max capacity decreases but the system is still able to handle the "average" load (which is 50% of all blocks being full) so why not design the economic mechanism to target that. In my opinion there is no downside, can you tell me any?

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> I think the only effect is that basefee is a bit slower at ramping up in case there is a surge. Not sure if that's such a big deal

author: jgm
content:
I suppose this somewhat comes down to the question of if an average of 50% full blocks with every block present is different from (e.g.) 75% full blocks with 2/3 of blocks present.  For me it feels like the latter situation should be considered more constrained capacity and as a result incur a higher base fee, as there is less headroom for spikes and so it diminishes one of the strengths of EIP-1559's design.

That said, this is only off the top of my head and I haven't thought very deeply about it.
